“The world has squandered so much time mustering the action necessary to combat climate change that rapid, unprecedented cuts in greenhouse gas emissions offer the only hope of averting an ever-intensifying cascade of consequences” https://www.washingtonpost.com/climate-environment/2019/11/26/bleak-report-un-says-drastic-action-is-only-way-avoid-worst-impacts-climate-change/#comments-wrapper …

In honor of Brooklyn, Brianna, and Ja’leyah, I ask that we all do just a little bit more to create the changes needed to protect ALL Americans, regardless of who they are or who they love.

Despite marginal gains in state and local policies that support transgender people, there are few legal protections for those who identify as transgender and gender-expansive. Change is needed to protect our LGBTQ friends.

3 individuals with full lives ahead of them, cut short by hatred and senseless violence. Their lives were unfinished and their dreams left incomplete. The loved ones left behind and the communities they made better will miss them dearly.

Brooklyn Lindsay was 32 and enjoyed dancing, helping others, and wanted to be a life coach. 
 
Ja’leyah Jamar was 30 and passionate about working on cars, designing hair, and spending time with family.
 
Brianna Hill was 30, a fan of the Chiefs, and beloved by her community.

This year alone, at least 22 transgender and gender non-conforming Americans have been killed in the US. 91% of them were black women. 3 of those individuals were killed in the Greater Kansas City Area.  We must be better than this as a nation.

Last night, on #TransgenderDayOfRemembrance, I spoke on the House floor to condemn the senseless and reprehensible violence we continue to see against the trans community. Watch here: pic.twitter.com/0fHmyMji9d

The @senatemajldr's shameful decision to resist the will of the American people by stalling bipartisan gun legislation is literally costing us the lives of friends and family. #EnoughIsEnough! https://twitter.com/RepAdams/status/1197289259675398144 …

Latina women make 54 cents on the dollar as compared to non-Hispanic white men. Latinas and their families can’t afford to wait for the wage gap to close. That’s why the Senate must pass the #PaycheckFairnessAct! #LatinaEqualPayDay pic.twitter.com/loJqpH9qNf

In order to protect against gender or racial bias, it’s important that internet companies have a diverse workforce that reflects the perspectives and life experiences of all Americans. I will continue engaging with @InternetAssn to make sure that happens. https://cleaver.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/internet-association-releases-report-on-diversity-in-tech-following …

After @RepBonnie and I called for the @InternetAssn to make a concerted effort in diversifying their workforce, they responded by creating a position to do just that. This report is a byproduct of that decision. https://cleaver.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/internet-association-responds-to-congressman-cleaver-s-call-for …

Happy to see the @InternetAssn taking a proactive approach to improve workforce #diversity, which will benefit the internet and all of its users as a whole. While this report is a good start, we now must use the data to create #DiversityAndInclusion best practices. https://twitter.com/InternetAssn/status/1196802211252191232 …

To me, equality means freedom from hate, violence, and bigotry. On #TransgenderDayofRemembrance, I’m thinking of all the transgender American lives we’ve lost –– together, let’s commit to loving our neighbors, regardless of their gender identity. Let’s be better. pic.twitter.com/KjrUO4ezRz

I want to thank the Minority Corporate Counsel Association, the National Association of Minority and Women Owned Law Firms, @DiversityLabCo, @Microsoft, @HP, and @Dell for participating in this panel. I look forward to further engagement on this issue moving forward.

I believe that Big Tech companies, with their sizable influence, have an opportunity to create significant, lasting progress if they simply make the effort to diversify their outside counsel. That’s why I’m working with industry leaders to do more.

According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, law is one of the least racially-diverse professions in the US. Even when women and minorities are brought on board, they are promoted at disproportionately lower rates.

Yesterday, I hosted a panel to discuss lack of diversity in the legal profession. We heard from legal diversity advocates and select Big Tech companies to learn about the challenges and potential solutions to improving diversity in legal representation. https://cleaver.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/congressman-cleaver-hosts-panel-to-discuss-lack-of-diversity-in-legal …

I’ve been proactively working to ensure TRIA does not lapse at the end of the year by holding a panel with local stakeholders in KC in May and a subcommittee hearing on this legislation last month. Now, let’s pass this bill in the Senate and sign it into law!

Last year, nearly 1,800 children in Missouri were adopted. However, there are still nearly 2,800 children waiting to find a family. This #NationalAdoptionMonth, I urge everyone to reflect on the gift of adoption and how we can help those seeking forever homes.

Stacy Mays has adopted 6 children(!) and dedicated her life to advocating for adoption services. Her family is a living testament to the benefits of adoption and the importance of appropriate foster care and adoption services. You can read about the family below. pic.twitter.com/6U1whWTaR6

This #NationalAdoptionMonth, I’m proud to showcase the power of adoption by participating in @Voice4_Adoption’s Adoptive Family Portrait Project. This month, I’ve displayed the Mays family from Blue Springs, MO in my congressional office in efforts to raise awareness. pic.twitter.com/lH3nHfeQjP
